Award.AwardTitle: Transient Intermediates in Proton and Electron Transfer
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation supports Professor Frank Turecek of the University of Washington, for mass spectrometry studies of electron capture dissociation and electron transfer dissociation reactions in biomacromolecules. The goal of this research is to provide new identification methods for peptides and proteins, including structural features connected to non-covalent interactions (tertiary structure) and post-translational modifications.

Broader impacts of the research are based on Professor Turecek's unique abilities to use his knowledge of organic ion reaction mechanisms and computational chemistry to assess energy distribution in these reactive intermediates, and his group's ability to design and build novel instrumentation for mass spectrometry. His research group gains expertise across a broad range of disciplines. The results of their investigations on peptide structure impact the fields of biochemistry and the pharmaceutical industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Proteins are justifyingly called the “molecules of life” because they perform the majority of functions in living cells. Understanding protein structure and functioning is therefore critical for biology and medicine, development of new drugs, and disease diagnostics. In contrast to the DNA that can be amplified and rapidly analyzed, protein analysis is difficult because of their molecular complexity, variability, and enormous dynamic range with which proteins are found in cells and body fluids. Mass spectrometry is the premier analytical method that is being developed for protein analysis. The reported research has addressed the chemistry and mass spectrometry of peptides which are not only the building blocks of proteins, but also perform various functions in living organisms, such as hormones, antimicrobial compounds, signaling compounds, but also as various fungal, insect, mollusk, and vertebrae toxins. The particular specialized area of this research concerned peptide radicals, which are reactive species that are encountered in nature, but also are useful intermediates of peptide analysis by mass spectrometry. Peptide radicals occur naturally as intermediates of several enzymatic reactions, but others play a role in protein degradation caused by aging, ultraviolet light exposure, or radiation  damage.  The PI and his research group have been developing new methods for determining peptide radical structure and chemistry. The latter is studied for isolated peptide radicals that carry a positive charge, called cation-radicals, that are amenable to mass spectrometry.  We have been studying peptide cation-radical electronic structure and dissociations that allow us to tease out amino acid sequences and their effect on peptide chemical reactions. We have also developed new synthetic methods for chemically modifying peptides to affect their dissociations and thus improve sequencing by mass spectrometry.  In the reported research, new experimental and computational methods have been implemented to bear on peptide cation-radical structure and chemistry. Unusual structures (shown in the accompanying image) and electronic properties have been discovered for some peptide cation-radicals that have changed our view of gas-phase ion chemistry.


Last Modified: 10/01/2015
Modified by: Frantisek Turecek

Image
  • Steric model of a Gly-Leu-Gly-Gly-Lys peptide cation radical obtained by high-level calculations in support of an experimental study. The atoms are color-coded by green = carbon, gray = hydrogen, blue = nitrogen, and red = oxygen.
    From the PI's archive
    Public Domain
    Frantisek Turecek
    Peptide cation-radical
